work.p:
Lines from this manuscript appeared as the following, in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself": "All truths wait in all things, / They neither hasten their own delivery nor resist it, / They do not need the obstetric forceps of the surgeon, / The insignificant is as big to me as any, / What is less or more than a touch? /
Logic and sermons never convince, / The damp of the night drives deeper into my soul. /
Only what proves itself to every man and woman is so, / Only what nobody denies is so" (1855, p. 33).

Lines in this manuscript bear some similarity to sentences in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass. See, for instance, the lines: "Whatever satisfies the soul is truth" (1855, p. xi) and "What the eyesight does to the rest he does to the rest. Who knows the curious mystery of the eyesight? The other senses corroborate themselves, but this is removed from any proof but its own and foreruns the identities of the spiritual world" (1855, p. v).

titleStmt.title: There can be nothing small
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Lines from the manuscript appear in the first poem in that edition, titled "Leaves of Grass," eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: There can be nothing small
bibl.orgName: The manuscript was sold by Sotheby's in 2008. The current location of the manuscript is unknown.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l: There can be nothing little small or trifling useless in the universe;
The insignificant grows as tall spreads as far is as much big as the noble;
What is less than a sheathed? touch?
All truths stand wait in all things; places;

The wait with inclined heads and arms folded
over their breasts;
They neither urge their own birth nor resist it;

They do not need the obstetric forceps of the
surgeon;

They unclose to whoever fetches the heat warmth of
the sunshine light and the moisture
of rain.—

add.l: Only What fully satisfies the senses if all all is truth;

lg.l: Logic and sermons never convince; me;
The dew of the night drives deeper into my the soul.—

add.l: An eternal A test of any thing!
It proves itself to the experience and senses of all men and women!

lg.l:
Bring it to folks any thing, and you will see whether
they doubt;
We They do not doubt contact or hunger or love;
We They do not doubt our fingers and toes; paving stones nor iron or steam;
We do not doubt the truth being mystery of hunger and of life, pain growth;
We do not doubt the east or the west;
